captions.text:
Nobody enjoys every kind of game universally. 
You&#39;d be hard-pressed to find someone who equally

enjoys playing Guitar Hero and, say, that weird 
DS game about touching underaged girls. Okay,

bad example. The point is, all game critics 
must necessarily specialize to a certain degree,

and I guess one of the things I now specialize 
in is cleaning games. Oh yes, if you&#39;re looking

for the game with the most authentic sound 
of a wet mop slapping against a tile floor

because you want to sample it for your indie 
visual novel about a sexually aggressive patio,

then apparently, I&#39;m the guy to ask. Cleaning and 
tidying games seem to be a now firmly established

up-and-coming indie genre; it effectively covers 
the twin demographics of fussy dads who want to

take satisfaction in a job well done and little 
giggling boys who want to draw huge cocks and

balls in grimy surfaces. But up until now, 
there&#39;s never been a cleaning game with much

in the way of an overarching story, unless you 
count the epic saga of &quot;very grimy room.&quot; With

the jaw-dropping second act twist &quot;there&#39;s 
still quite a lot of grime in this room.&quot;

Crime Scene Cleaner attempts to address this 
shortfall by giving us the story of Kowalski,

who, in contrast to having one of those names 
that fits really well on the end of the phrase

&quot;you&#39;re a loose cannon,&quot; is a mild-mannered 
high school janitor who cleans up one itty

bitty dead drug dealer as a favor to a mate and 
finds himself drawn into the underworld as the

go-to guy for dematerializing massacres—try 
to say that 10 times fast—struggling as he

goes with the morality of taping up bin 
bags full of innocent witnesses all night,

but it&#39;s okay &#39;cos he&#39;s doing it to pay for 
treatment for his critically ill daughter, whom

we never actually see but I&#39;m assuming has blonde 
hair in pigtails and sparkly, blue, innocent eyes

and chubby cheeks and a tattoo across her forehead 
reading &quot;insert cancer for free unquestionable

character motivation.&quot; As I mentioned when I 
covered the demo for this game in Yahtzee Tries,

the whole &quot;sick daughter&quot; thing is pretty eye-roll 
inducing; it&#39;s the kind of thing that gets put in

a screenplay as &quot;insert better motive later,&quot; and 
you end up having to go with because you can&#39;t

reach the writer on the first day of shooting &#39;cos 
they&#39;re passed out in someone&#39;s cocaine ball pit.

Anyway, Crime Scene Cleaner adopts a 
mission-based structure that reminded me

pleasantly of my beloved Thief games, only you&#39;re 
creeping carefully around huge, opulent buildings

not because you might alert guards but because 
you don&#39;t want to leave bloody footprints on the

bits you&#39;ve already mopped. Also, each level has 
multiple secrets for an enterprising explorer and

are dotted with drug stashes, jewelry, and silver 
urns containing beloved deceased relatives for

Kowalski to pawn for extra cash, but it&#39;s okay, 
he&#39;s got a sick daughter, remember. And obviously,

once she&#39;s out of hospital, he can&#39;t expect her to 
come home to anything less than a 70-inch plasma

screen, can he? So that all adds some lovely 
exploration spice to the core cleaning gameplay,

which manages to find the midpoint between 
previous cleaning game luminaries Viscera Cleanup

Detail and PowerWash Simulator by including the 
bucket-of-water-based resource management of the

former and the, erm, power washer of the latter. 
The power washer kind of sucks a big fat scrub

daddy if you&#39;re not prepared to sink several 
missions&#39; worth of upgrade points into it,

but what&#39;s a game supposed to do, NOT have 
the inevitable fucking skill tree that means

all your tools start out about as effective as 
a laundry pole with a Q-tip taped to the end?

Even the fucking flashlight you have to unlock, 
and then you need to invest more points to give

the battery a higher life expectancy than a 
four-pack at an AA meeting. And the environments

are usually pretty fucking dark, &#39;cos you don&#39;t 
hoof corpses into your trunk at 11 in the morning,

cheerfully nodding to the mailman as you pass. On 
the whole, I&#39;d say the mop slapping action doesn&#39;t

have quite the satisfying, visceral cleaning 
action that, erm, Viscera Cleanup Detail had,

but I admire Crime Scene Cleaner&#39;s greater 
depth of strategy. You have to figure out when

a situation calls for a mop and when for the good 
old Scrub Daddy. Sure, the mop will make short

work of the kitchen worktop, but the investigating 
officers might get weird about all the broken wine

glasses. Is it better to clean first or leave that 
until after you&#39;ve rearranged the furniture? What

combination of cleaning fluids most optimally 
meets the current requirements for strength,

lastability, and providing an inexpensive, mellow 
high when inhaled? I think it&#39;s fair to say Crime

Scene Cleaner provides the most varied and 
sophisticated cleaning gameplay we&#39;ve yet

seen in the genre, and it&#39;s certainly worth a 
play to my fellow post-dad game enthusiasts.

That said, for being the cleaning game that 
finally puts some effort into the story,

I wish it&#39;d put more effort into the story. 
The main character comes across as kind of

a prick. &quot;How dare you, Yahtz? He&#39;s got a sick 
daughter.&quot; Don&#39;t I fucking know. I bet he never

shuts up about it when he&#39;s at a dinner party 
and brings the whole atmosphere down. The witty,

sarcastic asides that made Garrett seem like 
a dry, cool badass make Kowalsky seem like a

passive-aggressive twat; he&#39;ll mutter under his 
breath about how naughty our boss was to murder

all these innocent people but never actually 
consider NOT working for the guy. There&#39;s

even a level where he cleans up the body of the 
friend who got him this gig in the first place,

and that still doesn&#39;t give him pause 
for thought. &quot;Them&#39;s the breaks!&quot; he

murmurs philosophically has he struggles to 
close his trunk on the stiffening flesh of

his only established ally like it&#39;s a stubborn 
suitcase in an overhead bin. You wanna know the

dramatic conclusion to all this—spoiler 
alert? After the final story mission,

our gangland boss gets arrested, not because 
of anything we did, and Kowalsky dramatically

and heroically declares, &quot;Probably gonna chuck in 
the crime scene cleaning now, not really into it.&quot;

That&#39;s it? Where&#39;s the consequence? Where&#39;s 
the lessons learned? Besides &quot;don&#39;t use a power

washer to clean a crystal glassware cabinet&quot;? 
What about the daughter&#39;s treatment? And how

will she feel about what you did to pay for it? 
And what about every other underworld figure who

still has your email address, dumbass? What, 
you think blocking them on Instagram&#39;s gonna

stop them nailing your dog&#39;s head to your front 
door? So, not a fully positive takeaway. Y&#39;know,

I&#39;ve brought this up before, but I still wonder 
why no one&#39;s thought of making a combined

assassination and cleaning game. I feel like that 
would appeal to logistics-minded Hitman-enjoying

types. As well as waiting until the target is 
isolated, you&#39;d also need to ensure they&#39;re

not next to any soft furnishings and not arouse 
their suspicions following them around with six

tarpaulins under your arm. And then make sure 
no witnesses interrupt you by putting a load of

little orange cones around the floor. I mentioned 
this to my wife, and she pointed out that the

audience for badass assassination games and the 
audience for cleaning sims probably don&#39;t overlap

as much as I think. Not many people want to see 
Agent 47 strap on a little headscarf and pinny,

clicking open a pristine silver attaché 
case to reveal a fucking Dustbuster.
